What is more commonly referred to as ``geometric Satake" is not an equivalence, but a functor in one direction, which we will refer to as ``naive Satake" and…

statement_preview: As in the case of \thmref{t:geom CS}, for the validity of \thmref{t:geom Satake} at the factorization level, it is crucial that we work with the twisted category $$\Dmod_{\frac{1}{2}}(\fL^+(G)\backslash \fL(G)/\fL^+(G))$$ rather than with $\Dmod(\fL^+(G)\backslash \fL(G)/\fL^+(G)…

section: Geometric Satake and Casselman-Shalika formula: recollections
statement_preview: One thing that is naive about the naive Satake functor is its direction. Our conventions are that functors in geometric Langlands go from the geometric side to the spectral side. However, the naive Satake functor produces sheaves from representations.

We shall say that $\ul\sF$ satisfies Global Unitality Axiom 2 if the natural transformation \eqref{e:unitality transform} is an isomorphism (for any $\CZ\to \Ran$).

label: t:main
section: The Langlands functor is an equivalence on the Eisenstein part(s)
statement_preview: \label{t:main} Let us assume that GLC is valid for Levi subgroups of all proper parabolics of $G$. Then the adjoint functors in \eqref{e:Lang Eis} are mutually inverse equivalences.

Note that the proof of \corref{c:L ff on cusp} shows that it is actually logically equivalent to \thmref{t:coeff ff on cusp}. Hence, once we establish GLC, we will know that \thmref{t:coeff ff on cusp} also holds for any $G$.

Alternatively, the proof of the existence of a non-zero Hecke eigensheaf for a given irreducible local system, valid for any $G$, follows by combining the \cite{BD1} construction of Hecke eigensheaves via localization at the critical level and the result of \cite{Ari}, which says…

label: t:left adj as dual
statement_preview: \label{t:left adj as dual} The functor $\Phi_{G,\on{cusp}}$ identifies canonically with $\BL^L_{G,\on{cusp}}$.

label: t:right adj as dual
statement_preview: \label{t:right adj as dual} The functor $\Phi_{G,\on{cusp}}$ identifies canonically with the right adjoint of $\BL_{G,\on{cusp}}$.

label: t:ambidex
statement_preview: \label{t:ambidex} The left and right adjoints of $\BL_{G,\on{cusp}}$ are isomorphic.

label: c:comp self-adj
statement_preview: \label{c:comp self-adj} The endofunctor $$\BL_{G,\on{cusp}}\circ \BL^L_{G,\on{cusp}}$$ of $\QCoh(\LS^{\on{irred}}_\cG)$ is isomorphic to its own left and right adjoint.

label: c:A G irred
statement_preview: \label{c:A G irred} The object $\CA_{G,\on{irred}}\in \QCoh(\LS^{\on{irred}}_\cG)$ is self-dual. In particular, it belongs to $\QCoh(\LS^{\on{irred}}_\cG)^{\on{perf}}$, i.e., it is compact.

label: t:A G irred
statement_preview: \label{t:A G irred} The object $\CA_{G,\on{irred}}\in \QCoh(\LS^{\on{irred}}_\cG)$ is a classical vector bundle, which is equipped with a naturally defined flat connection\footnote{Note that \corref{c:A=B Op} and \propref{p:finite monodromy} imply that the resulting local system…

Note that it makes sense to talk about classical vector bundles on $\LS^{\on{irred}}_\cG$, since, under the assumption that $\cG$ is semi-simple, the stack $\LS^{\on{irred}}_\cG$ is classical and smooth.

label: p:Loc crit is Loc
statement_preview: \label{p:Loc crit is Loc} The functor $\Loc_{G,\on{cusp}}$ is Verdier quotient.

label: p:Loc crit and dual

statement_preview: \label{t:BG via Op} There exists a canonical isomorphism between $$\CB_{G,\on{irred}}\simeq \CB^{\Op}_{G,\on{irred}}$$ as plain objects of $\QCoh(\LS^{\on{irred}}_\cG)$.

One can show that the isomorphism of \thmref{t:BG via Op} respects the co-associative coalgebra structures on the two sides. However, we will neither prove\footnote{See, however, Remark \ref{r:coalg}.} nor use this.

label: c:A=B

label: c:BG is compact
statement_preview: \label{c:BG is compact} The object $\CB^{\Op}_{G,\on{irred}}\in \QCoh(\LS^{\on{irred}}_\cG)$ is compact.

label: p:finite monodromy
statement_preview: \label{p:finite monodromy} The local system $\ul\CB^{\Op}_{G,\on{irred}}$ has a finite monodromy, i.e., it trivializes over a finite \'etale cover of $\LS^{\on{irred}}_\cG$.
The homology of the fibers of the map $\pi^{\on{irred}}_\Ran$ is acyclic off degree $0$.
The connected components of the fibers of the map $\pi^{\on{irred}}_\Ran$ are homologically contractible.

label: c:oper contr
statement_preview: \label{c:oper contr} The space of \emph{generic oper structures} on a given irreducible local system is homologically contractible.

Note that the ``bottom" layer of \conjref{c:oper contr} says that the space of generic oper structures on a given irreducible local system is \emph{non-empty}. This statement is actually a theorem, thanks to \cite{Ari}.

The assertion of \conjref{c:oper contr} is easy for $G=GL_n$. In particular, in this way we obtain another proof of GLC in this case (i.e., one that is logically different from that in \secref{ss:GLn})\footnote{The difference between the two arguments is that one uses a fully fai…

label: t:GLC for class
statement_preview: \label{t:GLC for class} The geometric Langlands conjecture holds when $G$ is a classical group.

label: c:change group
section: Reduction to the case when \texorpdfstring{$G$}{G} is almost simple and simply-connected
statement_preview: \label{c:change group} Suppose that the functor $\BL_{G_1}$ is an equivalence. Then so is $\BL_{G_2}$.

label: c:prel sc
section: Reduction to the case when \texorpdfstring{$G$}{G} is almost simple and simply-connected
statement_preview: \label{c:prel sc} If GLC holds for $G_{\on{sc}}$, then it also holds for $G$.

label: c:sc
section: Reduction to the case when \texorpdfstring{$G$}{G} is almost simple and simply-connected
statement_preview: \label{c:sc} If GLC holds for all $G$ that are almost simple and simply-connected, then it holds for any reductive $G$.

statement_preview: \label{p:genus 1} Let $\sG$ be an adjoint group different from $PGL_n$. Then for a curve of genus $1$, we have $\LS_\sG^{\on{irred}}=\emptyset$.

The map \eqref{e:to gerbes} means that to a $\cG$-bundle we can canonically associate an \'etale $\pi_1(\cG)$-gerbe. Namely, this is the gerbe of \'etale-local lifts of our bundle to the simply-connected cover of $\cG$.

label: p:pi 1 Bun
statement_preview: \label{p:pi 1 Bun} The map \eqref{e:to gerbes} defines an isomorphism of $\tau_{\leq 1}$ truncations of \'etale homotopy types.

label: t:pi 1 LS

statement_preview: \label{c:LS CM} The stack $\LS_\cG$ is Cohen-Macaulay of dimension $\dim(\fg)\cdot 2(g-1)$.

label: p:compl 2
statement_preview: \label{p:compl 2} Excluding the case of $g=2$ with the root system of $G$ containing an $A_1$ factor, the complement to $\LS_\cG^{\on{irred}}$ in $\LS_\cG$ has codimension $\geq 2$.

label: c:compl 2
statement_preview: \label{c:compl 2} The embedding $\LS^{\on{irred}}_\cG\hookrightarrow \LS_\cG$ induces a bijection between the sets of connected components.

label: p:A irred
statement_preview: \label{p:A irred} The restriction of $\CA_{G,\on{irred}}$ to every connected component is isomorphic to a direct sum of lines bundles, each of which is a restriction of some $\CL_{\CP_{Z_G}}$ (see \secref{sss:L P Z G}).
Note that the last step in the above argument shows that the map $$\CO_{\LS_\cG} \to \jmath_*(\CO_{\LS^{\on{irred}}_\cG})$$ also induces an isomorphism at the level of $H^0(\Gamma(\LS_\cG,-))$.

label: c:O on LS
statement_preview: \label{c:O on LS} For $g\geq 2$, for every connected component $\alpha$ of $\LS_\cG$, the map $$k\to \Gamma(\LS_{\cG,\alpha},\CO_{\LS_{\cG,\alpha}})$$ is an isomorphism.
One can prove \corref{c:O on LS} directly by a deformation argument using \cite[Theorem 4.2]{FT}.
We remark that Corollary \ref{c:O on LS} is a special feature of the de Rham setting; there are many more global functions on the Betti moduli stack.
